Problem:
Consider a magnetic field \\( \\vec{B} = B_0 e^{-kt} \\hat{z} \\), acting on a charged particle resulting in the Lorentz force equation \\( \\dot{\\vec{v}} = q (\\vec{v} \\times \\vec{B}) \\). We explore the effects of an applied electric field \\( \\vec{E} = E_0 \\hat{x} \\) as a transformation on the particle's motion.

If the electric field \\( \\vec{E} \\) is applied to a particle initially at rest, and then allowed to move under the influence of the magnetic field \\( \\vec{B} \\) without further intervention, will the particle's trajectory at time \\( T \\) be the same as if moved only due to \\( \\vec{B} \\) without \\( \\vec{E} \\)?
Explanation: The electric field \\( \\vec{E} \\) alters the initial velocity vector, which in turn affects how the Lorentz force directs the particle's path. The presence of an electric component introduces additional acceleration along the x-axis, modulating the trajectory compared to the magnetic field only condition.
